Posts.Title: I am really really scared and hoping for support.... Blossoms Blossoms

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2013 08:58PM ShelMel wrote: I totally agree with you, BouncingBetties. I find myself very much on the giving end of this disease, reassuring others that I will be okay and that I will always fight. I WANT to stay positive and upbeat, but it's impossible. I am personally very vocal about what's going on with me, sharing everything via FB with friends, family and now strangers who are friending me. I was very sick my second chemo round (high fever) and I thought I was dying. And I shared how scared I was and how hopeless I felt with my "world" and surprisingly, I had a lot of support. But yes, I get a lot of the "keep up the great attitude", "you're gonna beat this because you're just so positive" mantras, too. I'm going to look into that book you mentioned. I may pass it around to family. HA!
Posts.Title: Just think positive... BouncingBetties PinkShirtNow

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2013 09:54AM ShelMel wrote: I thought I'd join the ranks of introductions here. I'm fairly new to the Stage IV boards. My name is Shelle, I'm 41, mom of 3 - DS 16, DSS 14 and DD 6. I was a copywriter and marketing advertiser in the huge corporate world (and LOVED it) before I was diagnosed as stage 1, Grade 2 in 2010 at 39 years old. Had a lumpectomy with clear margins, took chemo and had radiation. I was declared NED in May 2011. I started Tamoxifen and then I stopped Tamoxifen after about a year because the SEs were too harsh. Had a full hysterectomy in August 2012 and then discovered Lung/Chest Wall mets two month after that in October 2012. It took until December 5, 2012, with a surgical lung biopsy to finally get the right tissue to confirm that it was indeed 100% mets. Immediately started a chemo cocktail and am having a scan this Friday to determine if it's working. I am a military wife, married to my soldier husband for 9 years, and he is THE BEST. I have the most amazing kids. Right now I'm still absorbing everything and trying to find a level of normal while I navigate these waters of chemos, scans, drugs and feeling like general crap half the time because of the chemo. I'm so grateful to be here. I am overwhelmed with the love and support from all of you. Thank you for embracing me into your world with open arms and loving hearts.

I may try some melatonin. Blessings!

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2013 12:44AM ShelMel wrote: I don't have bilateral breast cancer but I was diagnosed initially at age 39. I now have extensive mets (20-30 tumors) in my lungs & chest wall. And 1 sternum met. My case is rare too. I'm at the beginning of my stage IV journey. So I don't have much to offer you. But I highly recommend that you stick around here and read. The articles are great and the women here rock! You will find the best support here. I would be totally lost without these amazing women. In the meantime, take a deep breath, stay away from dr. Google. And know that there is always hope. I'll be here holding your hand in the meantime. Sending you a ton of hugs.

I say give yourself time to wallow, come here, vent, cry, let it out and then pick yourself back up and keep trudging forward again. Sending you very many hugs and much love.

Posts.Title: Stage IV - Estrogen positive - Bone Mets... Eva_V kebab

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2013 10:41AM ShelMel wrote: Thank you guys so much. I think I feel better now, just hearing from all of you. Kay - My onc told me that with the aggressivness of this cancer, if my first line of defense did not work, stastically, other options may not work either. Not sure why he said that. And maybe I misunderstood? But I don't think so. He said that there is nothing normal about my mets. If mets can be "normal". Moira - Thank you. I may need to look into some anti-depression meds. I hate taking them tho, they dull my senses and I don't like that, but with this, maybe I need to get back on them. Jennifer - I was stage 1, grade 2 with my initial breast cancer. For some reason I've got mets. No reason, I know it's not normal. I had a laproscopic lung biopsy with a chest tube on December 5th that finally confirmed the mets 100%. The FNA's (2 of them) were inconclusive. I haven't had Adriamycin yet. I think that may have been one of the chemo drugs that my onc mentioned I'd be doing. I will call him tomorrow with a clearer head and ask. 33skidoo - You rock!! And you're my hero!! Thank you. Ok. That makes me feel better. Love and prayers and hugs to all of you amazing women. I cannot even begin to express to you guys how much it helps to come here and read and vent and get responses that lift me up. It overwhelms me with gratitude. Thank you!
Posts.Title: Terrified and trying to hold it together ShelMel JTilCT

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2010 11:07PM ShelMel wrote: Hi babysister66 - I don't have any answers for you and what you're going through as I right at the beginning of this journey myself. Did they do a breast biopsy, too? If not, from what I understand, you won't know anything regarding your breast lump until then. I think... I'm sorry you're having so many health issues. I too, have excessive night sweats, but I haven't read anything about that being related to breast cancer, but that doesn't mean it doesn't. I wish I had more positive things to say to you about your questions. Please know that you're not alone. This board has been a God-send for me over the last 4 weeks while I wait on answers. I hate waiting. I'm more of a take-action kinda person. I'm sending you many hugs and prayers. Please keep us posted. I hope your health takes a turn for the better and you're able to stay in your nursing program. Try to stay busy this weekend. Blessings - Shelle

Posts.Title: Luke and Jesse's Mom, Cindy...Heaven's Newest Angel SarahsMom vickib

Posts.Content: ShelMel wrote: I'm new to the mets board - and was dx'ed with lung and chest mets. I had my lung biopsy to confirm it on December 5th. My onc put me on Arimidex and decided to do a baseline Chest and Abdoment CT scan. That scan was compared to my Chest CT scan that was done at the end of October, which found the lesions which led to me finally having the lung biopsy in December. I had an appointment with my onc yesterday to go over the baseline scan and it was bad. Real bad. From late October when we discovered the lesions to now - my tumors have doubled in size and I've developed new tumors. During that time, I was not on any meds, because all the needle biopsies I had were inconclusive. For the first time ever, my onc was not very optimistic. Of course we're going to fight this thing, but he was extremely matter of fact. I will start on chemo on Monday. My head was swimming when he was talking that I forgot to write down the chemo names. I know that 5FU was one of them and two others. I'm going in on Wednesday for an echo. My onc told me that if this chemo (my first line of defense) did not work, that it isn't likely that I will have other options that work. He said that if this doesn't work, I am looking at a few months - 6 months tops. I apparently have fluid in my lungs, caused from the cancer. I have 20-30 tumors in my lungs and about that many in my chest wall. He said this cancer is extremely agressive and that doesn't stastically bode well. My onc works under the Vanderbilt umbrella. I know that he will be checking on other options and trials. After receiving the mets diagnosis, I spent some time wrapping my head around "3-5" years and started making plans, to live, travel, experience life.... Now? I'm scared shitless. I don't want to spend the next few months sick as a dog and miss out on living. I'm going to do the chemo, no doubt, but damn it. Can I cuss here? I'm so freaked out and can't stop crying. I don't want to leave my babies. I'm not ready, they're not ready. This chemo HAS to work. It has to. Has anyone else had a diagnosis like this? I could use a dose of hope right about now please. ::::Life, Love, Hope, LIVE :::: mets to lungs, chest wall, sternum, liver, spleen, L5 spine Dx 9/27/2010, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/5 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Surgery 9/27/2010 Lumpectomy: Right Chemotherapy 12/2/2010 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Radiation Therapy 3/10/2011 Breast Hormonal Therapy 5/1/2011 Surgery 8/24/2012 Prophylactic ovary removal Dx 10/30/2012, IDC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Hormonal Therapy 12/18/2012 Arimidex (anastrozole) Chemotherapy 1/4/2013 Adriamycin (doxorubicin), Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Fluorouracil (5-fluorouracil, 5-FU, Adrucil) Chemotherapy 5/15/2013 Carboplatin (Paraplatin), Taxol (paclitaxel) Chemotherapy 7/16/2013 Halaven (eribulin) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Some days are darker than others. pattih

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2012 09:53PM ShelMel wrote: Hi sweet ladies - I just wanted to know when I get to post in the METS board. Long story short I've had a Chest CT and PET scan that showed multiple lesions in my lungs and in my chest wall. After a lymph node and lung CT-guided biopsy that were both inconclusive, and a second opinion, both doctors are positive that it's mets. I'm meeting with the lung biopsy surgeon on Monday, they want me to get the biopsy done ASAP. The lung resection will most likely confirm what my doctors are saying. Sure, there's a tiny glimmer of hope that it "could" be something else, but the reality is that it's not likely. Both doctors said that the lesions are foci and because of number of them and location inside AND outside my lung, there's just not much hope that it's anything other than mets. I got my second opinion today so I'm in the middle of just absorbing that news and preparing to meet the lung surgeon. I'm kind of numb right now but I know the emotions are going to hit me hard very soon.

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2012 03:40PM ShelMel wrote: Thank you Scuttlers and Chrissy. I'm still in shock right now, I think. I don't really have any emotions and feel kind of detached from it. I've been reading the threads here and my heart breaks and then my heart bursts with joy at how much life you guys have. I don't know when it's going to hit me, but when it does, I'm probably gonna be a mess... for a little while. Right now my focus is on reassuring other people (friends/family). I've gotta get through reassuring them before I can get to me. I did that with my original dx for breast cancer. I guess that's normal, huh? I don't know what I would do without the boards here. When I went through my first breast cancer treatments, it was a God-send. I am sure this time around it's going to be even more of a God-send. :)

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2010 01:05PM ShelMel wrote: Hi Babysister66 -  I wanted to check up on you today. You sound better. As everyone has said, you're not alone. These boards are full of the most wonderfully supportive women who will love you, pray for you and support you as much as they can. With no insurance, I'm sure that has to be scary. As long as you pay what you can to your medical doctors and institutions, even if it's $5 a month, that's all you can do. Don't let the stress of paying medical bills keep you from getting better. Try not to worry so much. I know, it's easier said than done. I agree with chrissyb, don't worry about the scans that you've seen. Try to chill out this weekend and relax. If can, get a group of best girlfriends together and go window shopping or out to eat. Many prayers and wishes for a calm weekend. - Shelle

Posts.Title: Between a rock and a hard place lovinmomma

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2013 10:50AM ShelMel wrote: marywh - I truly do love my onc. and his bedside manner is good. He's never been this fatalistic before, ever. He's always been very upbeat and positive. I think the agressiveness and abnormalcy of how this is progressing is not very promising in his eyes. He said something as we were wrapping up that struck me as odd, even though all of us hear it all the time from others. He said, "You're braver than I am." I'm not sure why he said that and why it sounded so odd to me, but it did. I guess I just didn't expect to hear something like that from my oncologist. And if he thinks I'm brave, damn! I didn't fall out on the floor wailing while we talked, so maybe that's why he said that. I hate crying and I don't cry well or for long. I cry in short spurts, so maybe my lack of over-emotional response prompted that? Anyway, when I got home and thought about him saying that, it made me feel worse. Am I crazy?? LOL
